text: hey everybody Thomas Joseph here now
warm melt-in-your-mouth biscuits are a
classic favorite and today I'm gonna
share with you the perfect recipe for
making flaky and tender biscuits and you
won't end up with something like this a
squatty flat hard and crumbly biscuit so
let's get started to start off I have 3
cups of all-purpose flour here and I'm
using just a regular all-purpose flour
today but if you have access to any of
those really great soft wheat flours
like white lily flow'r that would be a
perfect thing to use for this recipe
because it'll give you something that's
really nice and tender in the end so
three cups of flour to that I'm gonna
add a tablespoon of sugar a little bit
of sweetness in your biscuit is really
really nice it helps to kind of offset
the saltiness from the salt and also
from the leavening that we're using so
two and a quarter teaspoons of baking
powder and this is double acting baking
powder and what that means again guys is
that it acts in two different stages
when you add moisture to it and also
heat so you'll have kind of a dual
leavening effect in addition to this
chemical leavener baking powder I'm
gonna add a little bit of baking soda
and this is three-quarters of a teaspoon
of baking soda and the baking soda is
gonna react at another stage when we add
acid into the biscuit dough last but not
least a little bit of salt I have a
teaspoon of kosher salt here now I'm
gonna whisk all these dry ingredients
together and I like to use a wire whisk
here because I think it helps to evenly
distribute all of that leavening and the
salt with the flour one tip if you're
making biscuits if you're making pie
crusts anything that has kind of that
flaky texture that you're hoping for in
the end it's helpful to have all of your
ingredients nice and icy cold so you can
even put your flour into the
refrigerator so this looks good and now
the butter so I have 10 tablespoons of
unsalted butter that's cut into I'd say
about half inch cubes I'm gonna add this
right to the flour and today I'm making
biscuits by hand but you could certainly
do this in a food processor if you
wanted to you could also use one of
those pastry cutters
that really works well now you want to
do this quickly so that you're not
melting the butter so I'm mashing the
butter up with my thumb and my fingers
trying to get some pea-sized pieces
that's what you're looking for and it
will take about two or three minutes to
achieve this all right so this looks
good you can see there are decent sized
pieces of butter in the flour mixture
and those little pieces of butter in the
end are gonna melt down in the oven and
they're gonna create steam which is
gonna help to leaven the biscuit so now
I'm gonna create a little bit of a well
in the center of the flour mixture and
I'm gonna add some buttermilk I have one
cup of icy cold buttermilk that I'm
using here today now a lot of you asked
the question hey I don't have access to
buttermilk or I don't really buy it so
what can I use instead and we did a
whole video on substitutes for
buttermilk so check that video out
taking a rubber spatula I'm gonna gently
pull the dry ingredients into the
buttermilk and I'm just gonna stir this
together until it's kind of crumbly and
shaggy you don't want this to be a
cohesive dough at this time so don't
overwork this mixture because that's how
you're gonna create a really tender
biscuit by avoiding over mixing so just
stir together until it almost comes
together and now I'm going to transfer
this onto a parchment lined baking sheet
and this parchment is gonna really help
me to bring this dough together and to
laminate the dough which is gonna give
us an extra flaky biscuit so using the
parchment here to help you what you're
gonna do is you're gonna take the two
sides of the parchment and kind of push
them together
lightly compressing the dough really
what you're looking to do here guys is
to just create a cohesive mass and then
I'm going to Pat the dough out into a
six by ten inch square and you know this
is kind of a loose measurement here guys
you can measure if you want to but
basically what we're doing here is we're
gonna
fold the dough on top of itself creating
even more layers and getting an extra
flaky biscuit so I'm gonna take this
rectangle use the parchment to help you
here and fold the dough in half and then
Pat this out again into a six by ten
inch rectangle roughly so now I'm gonna
fold it yet again in half and then at
this stage I'm going to push this guy
out to a six inch square and I'm making
square biscuits today but you could
certainly punch this out using a round
cutter that would be really great but
the benefit to cutting them into squares
is that you have no waste so this looks
like a rough six inch square and now I'm
gonna take a little bit of bench flour
I'm just gonna flour the top slightly
and I'm gonna flour my knife and I'm
gonna cut this into nine squares and you
can eyeball it now make sure your oven
is preheated to 450 degrees Fahrenheit
and I think it makes sense to have the
rack in the middle of the oven we're
looking for a pretty high temperature
here because we want to activate all of
the leaveners so high heat we want to
activate the butter so that it melts and
again it creates that wonderful steam
that's going to give you the flaky
layers to the biscuit and I'm going to
gently position the squares here about
I'm gonna give them a little bit of room
to grow so about 1/2 of an inch in
between you could leave them plain like
this or if you had a little bit of
buttermilk you can brush the top for a
really nice kind of golden brown crust
to these biscuits so these will take
around 18 minutes maybe 18 to 20 minutes
depending on how accurate your oven is
so right into the oven alright guys so
the biscuits are out of the oven and
they're cooled just ever so slightly now
you want to make sure that you're eating
these biscuits nice and warm that really
is the best way to enjoy them
look at how tall and flaky they are and
I mean they're just gorgeous
now you could serve these just as they
are maybe with a little bit of butter if
you wanted something sweet jam for a

a little egg sandwich because I think
that's what a biscuit really needs I
have a fried egg you could use scrambled
eggs a little bit of bacon cheese it's
really whatever you like and there you
